I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) for the Secondary Education Sector 
Development Project is included in the country operations business plan, 2011–2013. The Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) has been providing substantial assistance for the development of 
secondary education, including two projects: (i) the Teaching Quality Improvement in Secondary 
Education Project, which focuses on teacher strengthening; and (ii) the Secondary Education 
Sector Development Project, which is helping the government to reform the sector.1 A project 
preparatory TA is currently preparing the second Teaching Quality Improvement Project.2 ADB 
is also assisting in improving and mainstreaming madrasah education.3 The commitment of the 
Government of Bangladesh to education remains high. A National Education Policy (NEP), 
which proposes significant reforms to increase quality, access, and equity in education, has 
been  approved  by  the  cabinet  and  is  expected  to  be  tabled  during  the  next  session  of 
Parliament. Although the NEP sets out a vision, the implications of the proposed reforms for the 
secondary  education  sector  and  the  subsequent  implementation  strategy  have  yet  to  be 
analyzed and developed. The government has therefore requested the support of the ADB in 
analyzing the implications of the NEP for secondary education and preparing an implementation 
strategy. The TA was discussed and approved during a fact-finding mission in August 2010.4 
The government concurred with the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, 
cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Bangladesh has made considerable progress in improving access to education at all 
levels,  despite  various  challenges  including  natural  disasters.  Enrollment  in  secondary 
education has improved; so have the transition, completion, and pass rates in examinations. 
Despite significant progress in access, quality and equity remain major challenges. Poor quality 
manifests  itself  in  unacceptably  high  dropout  rates,  although  these  are  improving,  and  in 
difficulties  encountered  by  secondary  education  graduates  in  finding  a  job  because  the 
curriculum  has  only  limited  relevance  for  the  job  market.  Children  from  poor  families  and 
disadvantaged groups do not have access to an education of acceptable quality, and have low 
completion rates and poor learning achievements.  
 
3.  Importance  of  secondary  education.  Globally,  secondary  education  is  expanding 
rapidly and putting enormous pressure on governments to respond quickly. In Bangladesh, the 
same thing is happening as more students are now graduating from primary education, which 
has a total enrollment of over 16 million in 5 grades. In contrast, the total enrollment in 7 grades 
in secondary education is little more than 50% of primary enrollment. The gross enrollment in 
secondary education is currently around 50% compared to over 100% at the primary level. This 
percentage for secondary education will rise fast, given the increasing numbers of primary 
education graduates. Secondary education has a vital role to play in providing technical and

vocational education and training, and preparing students for tertiary education and the labor 
market. The core skills and knowledge, such as analytical skills, literacy, communication, team 
work,  science,  math,  and  information  and  communication  technology  (ICT),  become  more 
critical at this stage.  
 
4.  Quality. Studies and analyses consistently show that poor quality of education remains 
the biggest challenge in Bangladesh, although improvements have been noted in secondary 
examination  results.  Factors  responsible  for  poor  quality  and  high  internal  inefficiency  are          
(i) poor teaching quality at the classroom level; (ii) high student–teacher ratios; (iii) low “time on 
task”;  (iv)  inadequate  teaching  and  learning  materials  and  other  school  facilities;  and                 
(v) overcrowded classrooms. The education system's success will depend on improving learning 
outcomes, particularly of the most disadvantaged groups. The government's sustained support 
for stipends has led to an expansion in enrollment, but targeting needs to continue to improve. 
 
5.  Access. As a result of its stipend policy, Bangladesh was one of the few developing 
countries to achieve gender parity up to secondary education by 2005, but different challenges 
remain.  The  proportion  of  female  students  starts  declining  after  grade  9  and  increases 
significantly  at  the  higher  secondary  level.  Although  more  female  students  are  enrolled  in 
secondary education, more male students complete secondary education. Enrollment in the 
science stream is dominated by male students. 
 
6.  Financing. At around 2.0% of GDP in FY2010, public expenditure in education remains 
low. Developing countries at a similar level of economic development invest much more in 
education, for example, around 3.5% of GDP in India and Viet Nam. While the government has 
recognized the need to increase investment in education, it is yet to be translated into the 
annual allocations.  
 
7.  Management and organization. Primary education is from grades 1 to 5, secondary 
from grades 6 to 10, and higher secondary from grades 11 to 12. Secondary education is 
offered in general secondary education schools, post-primary madrasahs, and some technical 
schools.  Only  2%  of  the  secondary  schools  are  government  schools  and  98%  are 
nongovernment.  The  nongovernment  schools  receive  100%  salary  support  for  approved 
teachers. There are wide variations among the nongovernment schools, in terms of quality, 
equity, and access indicators. Secondary education is weakly linked to needs in the job market. 
On average, government schools perform the best, followed by urban private, rural private, 
urban madrasah, and rural madrasah.5  
 
8.  The Ministry of Education (MOE) is responsible for overseeing and administering about 
20,000 secondary schools and 3,150 colleges, 2,728 technical education and vocational training 
institutions,  and  9,215  post-primary  madrasahs.  The  Directorate  of  Secondary  and  Higher 
Education  (DSHE)  is  responsible  for  all  secondary  schools.  The  Bangladesh  Madrasah 
Education  Board  under  MOE  is  responsible  for  designing  curricula,  holding  examinations, 
registering madrasahs, contracting out textbook production, and distributing textbooks. The 
Department of Technical Education and the Technical Education Board are responsible for 
managing technical secondary education. DSHE does not yet have an effective inspection and 
academic supervision system. A major issue is how to improve the quality of madrasahs and to 
mainstream them. The Ministry of Primary and Mass Education (MOPME) is responsible for 
primary education, but primary education in madrasahs or in secondary schools with a primary 
section is under the purview of the MOE.  
                                                 
5  CAMPE. 2007. Education Watch 2007: The State of Secondary Education – Quality and Equity Challenges. Dhaka.

3
 
9.  Globally, effective schools are associated with good head teachers that provide the 
leadership and accountability needed to improve school governance. The introduction of school-
based  management  and  leadership  at  all  levels  is  part  of  the  decentralized  approach  in 
Bangladesh.  Similarly,  school-based  planning  has  been  introduced  and  is  showing  good 
potential.  
 
10.  National Education Policy. The government’s commitment to education remains high. 
The National Education Policy (NEP), which emphasizes holistic and balanced development of 
the entire education sector, was approved by the cabinet on 31 May 2010 and is expected to be 
tabled for parliamentary approval in December. The NEP emphasizes the urgent need to enroll 
all  students  in  primary  education,  raise  the  literacy  level,  reduce  existing  disparities,  and 
improve the quality of education with a focus on teacher quality, school level leadership, more 
effective teacher training in the classroom, increased resources, targeted improvements, and 
monitoring of key results. The government's emphasis is on science and mathematics, English, 
and ICT. 
 
11.  The NEP has proposed a restructuring of school education: (i) the extension of primary 
education from grades 1–5 to grades 1–8, with grades 9–12 at the secondary level; and (ii) the 
integration of different types of primary and secondary schools into fewer types to reduce 
disparities. The government has emphasized revision of the curriculum to make it more relevant 
to the emerging needs of a rapidly modernizing economy, to provide more relevant teaching and 
learning materials, and to conduct examinations in grades 5, 8, 10, and 12 to ensure common 
learning outcomes for all children. The government aims to ensure that all children complete 
primary education, irrespective of their geographic, socioeconomic, ethnic, linguistic, gender, 
physical, and mental condition, with acceptable learning outcomes. The government recognizes 
the need to expand the secondary education system to provide better access for primary school 
graduates. The government is also focusing on mainstreaming the madrasah system to ensure 
equitable learning outcomes for all.  
 
12.  Need for an implementation strategy. The reforms planned in the NEP are expected 
to lead to major improvements in access, quality, equity, and relevance to the job market. 
Although the NEP has set out a vision, the actual implications of the reforms proposed in the 
NEP for the secondary education sector and its subsequent implementation strategy have yet to 
be analyzed and developed. This implementation strategy will be developed on the basis of 
analyses  of  the  institutional  implications  and  arrangements,  particularly  for  the  proposed 
restructuring of secondary education, of the sequencing of priorities for technical reforms, and of 
the financial and monitoring implications of the reforms.  
 
13.  Moving to a sector-wide approach. The government intends to adopt a sector-wide 
approach (SWAP) in secondary education. A SWAP based on the vision set out in the NEP 
would strengthen government ownership of the reforms. Moving towards a SWAP from the 
current project-based approach would support the aim to reduce the current fragmentation. 
Primary education reforms are supported by a SWAP, and since the NEP envisions close 
collaboration between  primary and secondary, a similar approach for secondary education 
should support implementation of the reforms. 6 Two major development partners (the World 
Bank and ADB) support secondary education, and more development partners are interested in 
giving their support. An agreed road map with indicative timeline towards a SWAP would 
                                                 
6  ADB is lead development partner in the primary education SWAP consisting of a consortium of 11 development 
partners. The next primary education support program is jointly being prepared.

4   
facilitate the involvement of other interested development partners and the harmonization of 
their assistance. During the analysis, lessons learned from the primary education SWAP and 
from international experience can support the identification of options for the type of SWAP that 
would be most suitable for secondary education in Bangladesh. 
 
14.  Critical  role  of  stakeholders. Extensive consultations with all stakeholders are an 
integral part of the analysis and development of the implementation strategy. The reforms in the 
NEP  are  significant,  and  this  approach  should  help  increase  the  understanding  of  the 
implications of the NEP and ownership for the chosen implementation strategy. Given the large 
role of nongovernment providers in secondary education, ownership of the reforms is required 
far beyond the public sector. This might require the development of new and innovative public–
private partnerships.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
15.  The TA will assist the government and the sector in analyzing the reforms of the NEP 
and will use this analysis to develop the implementation strategy through a consultative process. 
The implementation strategy will include steps to create the required institutional arrangements, 
a sequenced prioritization of technical improvements, a realistic financial scenario, steps to 
improve the monitoring arrangements for providing information on learning outcomes and for 
improving timely, accurate, and complete information on all schools, teachers, and students in 
secondary education, and a road map with indicative timeline to move towards the most suitable 
SWAP for secondary education. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The outcome will be agreement among key stakeholders on the implementation strategy 
of  the  NEP,  including  a  road  map  for  a  SWAP.  The  impact  will  be  the  decision  of  the 
government to implement the NEP in the secondary education subsector using a SWAP.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  In order to reach agreement among the key stakeholders, the TA will (i) produce and 
disseminate  an  analysis  of  institutional  arrangements,  priorities  for  technical  reforms,  and 
financial and monitoring implications of the secondary education reforms proposed in the NEP; 
(ii)  organize  consultations,  focus  group  discussions,  and  workshops  with  all  the  key 
stakeholders so they will understand the implications of the NEP better; 7 and (iii) organize a 
final workshop in which a draft implementation strategy for the NEP, including a road map with 
indicative timeline for a SWAP, will be submitted for agreement. The meaningful participation of 
all stakeholders in this process is required and assumed. Since the NEP has already been 
approved by the cabinet, it is assumed that the major reforms will be approved by Parliament 
during its next session. 
 
                                                 
7  Many stakeholders are involved in implementing the NEP in secondary education and need to be consulted: 
stakeholders at national level, MOE and its respective departments, MOPME and its respective departments, the 
education boards for the different types of education, other relevant ministries and agencies, (associations of) 
nongovernment education providers, private sector entities in education, universities, development partners, and 
teacher associations, and at the grass roots level students, teachers, parents, school managers and school 
administrators from different types of schools and institutions, and community and women’s groups.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $690,000 equivalent. The government has requested ADB 
to finance $600,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis, by ADB's Technical 
Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The  government  will  fund  $90,000  equivalent  in  kind 
through provision of office accommodation and transport, and remuneration and per diem for 
counterpart staff. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  MOE will be the executing agency for the TA, which is planned to commence in March 
2011 and complete by October 2011. An inter-ministerial steering committee, chaired by the 
secretary of MOE, will be established to guide overall implementation. All key government 
stakeholders, including MOPME and other relevant ministries, directorates and departments, 
and key nongovernment stakeholders, especially representatives of nongovernment secondary 
education providers like the Campaign for Popular Education (CAMPE), will be invited to join the 
steering  committee.  A  technical  committee  with  experts  from  the  key  stakeholders  will  be 
established in the Directorate of Secondary and Higher Education with its director general as 
the  chairperson  to  guide  the  technical  aspects  of  the  TA.  ADB  will  closely  monitor  TA 
implementation by reviewing the milestones and participating in some of the major consultative 
processes. 
 
20.  Consulting services will be provided for a total of 40 person-months, comprising 15 
person-months of international and 25 person-months of national consultants. The consultants 
will be engaged individually in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix 3. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time), and procurement of 
equipment will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Equipment  and  goods  procured  under  the  TA  will  be  handed  over  to  the  Government  of 
Bangladesh at the end of the project. 
 
21.  The analysis will be developed through consultations and focus group discussions with 
all stakeholders, with whom the analytical reports will then be discussed and shared. The draft 
implementation strategy, including a road map, will be developed based on these consultations. 
Agreement on the implementation strategy will be the goal of a final workshop. The results of 
the proposed TA are expected to feed into a project preparatory TA that is planned for 2012 to 
prepare the next ADB support for secondary education, which will adopt a SWAP.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Secondary Education Sector 
Development Project and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The TA will require 15 person-months of international consultants (4 consultants) and 25 
person-months of national consultants (4 consultants and a pool for 6 person-months). The 
consultants will be engaged individually in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  government  is  keen  to  start  the 
development of the implementation strategy as soon as possible after approval of the National 
Education Policy (NEP) in parliament. Some of the consultants will work on intermittent basis or 
will be recruited later on responding to the government requirements, which requires a flexible 
approach. The TA will be implemented over 7 months from when the consultants are first fielded. 
The TA team will deliver the outcomes and outputs of the TA as indicated in the TA paper. The 
TA team will help ADB and the Government of Bangladesh with any other assignments in 
addition to the terms of reference below, as may be reasonably expected within their scope of 
work. 
2.  The  TA  is  expected  to  assist  the  government  and  other  key  stakeholders  in  the 
development of an implementation strategy for the NEP, including a road map with indicative 
timeline for a sector-wide approach. The TA will support the government in completing an 
analysis that will form the basis of this strategy.  
3.  The following deliverables and activities are planned: 
(i)  Inception report (March 2011)  
(ii)  The first draft analysis report, based on document analysis and interviews with 
major stakeholders (June 2011). This report will analyze 
a.  institutional implications and options for institutional arrangements;  
b.  technical  reforms  and  options  for  the  sequencing  of  priority  technical 
reforms; 
c.  financial  scenarios  based  on  variables  like  enrollment  projections, 
increased efficiency, quality improvements, higher stipends, and financial 
decentralization; 
d.  implications for monitoring and measuring improved learning achievements 
and collecting accurate data; and 
e.  options for the introduction of a sector-wide approach 
(iii)  Focus group discussions to discuss the first draft analysis report (July 2011) 
(iv)  The final analysis report (August 2011) 
(v)  The first draft implementation strategy, including a road map for a SWAP based 
on additional consultations (September 2011) 
(vi)  A workshop to come to an initial agreement on the implementation strategy 
among key stakeholders (October 2011) 
(vii)  The final draft implementation strategy, including the road map, with a workshop 
report (October 2011) 
B.  International and National Experts 
  1.  Education Economist / Team Leader (international, 6 person-months) 
4.  The education economist / team leader will supervise the overall activities of the TA 
team. He/She is responsible for completion of the deliverables. In the analysis phase, the 
consultant is expected to be mostly involved in the institutional analysis and arrangements, the 
analysis of the technical reforms and their sequencing, and the financial scenario analysis. 
During the analysis phase, he/she will lead the analysis of the options for introducing a SWAP. 
The education economist will also (i) supervise the monitoring analyses carried out by the

10  Appendix 3 
 
education quality expert and the education data management expert; (ii) use the focus group 
discussions of the analysis to develop the implementation strategy, including the road map with 
indicative timeline for a SWAP; (iii) ensure the quality of the focus group discussions; (iv) guide 
the consultation process of the implementation plan, ensuring the participation of all relevant 
stakeholders at the national and grassroots level, such as students, parents, women’s groups, 
and community organizations; and (v) facilitate the high-level workshop where agreement on the 
implementation strategy will be sought. To provide this support, the education economist is 
expected to have knowledge of and experience in the education sector in Bangladesh and 
experience in introducing a SWAP in the education sector. The consultant is expected to be 
able to lead a TA team and facilitate high-level communication and workshops with senior 
officials. 
  2.  Comparative Education Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
5.  The comparative education specialist will be responsible for providing inputs on global 
experiences in secondary education reforms during the analysis phase, and assisting in the final 
discussion of the implementation strategy. The specialist will work closely with the team leader 
on the institutional analysis and arrangements, and on the analysis of the technical reforms and 
the priority sequencing. Where possible, inputs can be given for the financial and monitoring 
analysis. During the consultations, focus group discussions, and the final workshop, lessons 
learned from global experiences can assist in discussing and developing the implementation 
strategy. To provide this support, the specialist is expected to have a thorough knowledge of 
and experience in education systems in several countries, preferably in the reform of secondary 
education systems. Experience with secondary education in Bangladesh is an asset. 
3.  Education Quality Specialist (international, 3 months) 
6.  The education quality specialist will be responsible for (i) providing inputs on quality 
improvements to each part of the analysis, and (ii) analyzing the implications of the NEP on the 
assessment and examination system. Being able to measure how well the system contributes to 
actual  learning  achievements  and  to  make  appropriate  improvements  is  essential  for  the 
success of the reform. The analysis needs to focus on the systemic level: what will the new 
examination and assessment system look like, what is the system like now, and how can the 
current system be changed to the new system? Where possible, the national experts, the team 
leader, and the comparative education specialist will support the education quality specialist. 
The education quality expert is also expected to assist the team leader with the analysis of 
technical reforms and the priority sequencing. To provide this support, the specialist is expected 
to  have  a  thorough  knowledge  of  and  experience  in  (i) quality  improvement  in  education, 
preferably secondary education, and (ii) the design and reform of examination and assessment 
systems  to  measure  quality  improvements.  Preferably,  the  specialist  will  have  worked  in 
education in several developing countries and with knowledge of examination and assessment 
systems. Experience with quality improvement and examination and assessment systems in 
Bangladesh is an asset. 
  4.  Education Data Management Expert (international, 2 person-months) 
7.  The  education  data  management  expert  will  be  responsible  for  the  analysis  of  the 
implications of the NEP on the provision of timely, accurate, and complete information on all the 
schools, teachers, and students in secondary education. This analysis will focus on how the 
current  data  collection,  storage,  and  usage  system  needs  to  be  reformed  to  improve  the 
monitoring of the secondary education system. It also needs to focus on the systemic level: 
what will the new data system look like, what is the system like at the moment, and how can the 
current system be changed to the new system? The education data management expert will 
work closely with the national education statistics and data management expert. The other

Appendix 3  11 
national experts, the team leader and the comparative education specialist will support the 
education data management expert. The expert will also assist in the other analyses, where 
possible. To provide this support, the expert is expected to have knowledge of and experience 
in  designing,  implementing,  and  reforming  education  data  management  systems,  with  a 
particular focus on data collection, storage, and usage, preferably in developing countries. 
Experience with the Bangladesh Bureau of Educational Information and Statistics (BANBEIS) is 
an asset. 
5.  Coordinator (national, 7 person-months) 
8.  The coordinator will work closely with the team leader and provide in-depth experience 
and knowledge of the political economy in the education sector in general and of the political 
economy of the NEP in particular. During the analysis phase, the coordinator will (i) assist in the 
institutional analysis and arrangements, and in the analysis of options for introducing the SWAP; 
(ii) provide a “political economy” reality check of every analysis; and (iii) help to ensure the 
involvement of all the key stakeholders during the TA, especially during the development and 
discussion of the implementation strategy.  
15.  During the development of the implementation strategy, the coordinator, together with 
the team leader, will (i) ensure the proper design of the consultation and decision making 
process within MOE, with other agencies in the government, and with all other key stakeholders, 
(ii) ensure the quality of the focus group discussions, based on extensive knowledge of the key 
stakeholders in the sector, (iii) guide the consultation process of the implementation plan, and 
(iv) facilitate the high-level workshop where agreement on the implementation strategy will be 
sought. To provide this support the coordinator is expected to have in-depth knowledge of and 
experience  at  a  senior  level  in  education  policy  and  management  in  Bangladesh.  The 
coordinator needs to be familiar with all the stakeholders in the education sector and have 
ample  experience  in  foreign  assistance  programs  and  projects.  Relevant  background  in 
education policy and management is required. 
  6.  Secondary Education Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
9.  The secondary education specialist will work closely with the comparative education 
specialist and the education quality specialist, focusing on education quality improvement in 
each part of the analysis. In the analysis phase, the specialist will (i) focus on the analysis of the 
technical reforms and the priority sequencing, and on the analysis of the implications for the 
examination and assessment system, and (ii) take the lead in the consultations supporting these 
analyses. The specialist will then help to (i) develop the implementation strategy, including the 
road map, with a focus on quality improvements, based on the focus group discussions; (ii) 
ensure the quality of the focus group discussions; (iii) guide the consultation process of the 
implementation  plan;  and  (iv)  facilitate  the  high-level  workshop,  where  agreement  on  the 
implementation  strategy  will  be  sought.  To  provide  this  support  the  secondary  education 
specialist is expected to have extensive experience and knowledge of the education sector in 
Bangladesh, in particular quality improvements in secondary education. 
  7.  Public Finance Specialist (national, 3 person-months) 
10.  The public finance specialist will work closely with the team leader in conducting the 
analysis  of  financial  scenarios,  based  on  variables  like  enrolment  projections,  increased 
efficiency, quality improvements, stipends, and or financial decentralization. The specialist will 
take the lead in (i) analyzing the public and other expenditure required to implement the NEP; 
and  (ii)  conducting  the  consultations  supporting  the  financial  analysis.  The  Medium-Term 
Budget  Framework  (MTBF)  will  be  used  to  help  with  this  analysis  and  identify  a  realistic 
scenario for the implementation strategy. Based on the financial analysis, the specialist will

12  Appendix 3 
 
provide inputs to identify the most feasible sequencing of priority reforms. To provide this 
support  the  specialist  should  have  knowledge  of  and  experience  in  public  finance  in 
Bangladesh, financial scenario analysis, the MTBF, and the financing of secondary education. 
8.  Education Statistics and Data Management Specialist (national, 3 person-
months) 
11.  The  education  statistics  and  data  management  specialist  will  be  responsible  for 
providing statistical support for the financial scenario analysis and the sequencing of priorities 
by providing student and other projections on secondary education in line with the reforms 
suggested  in  the  NEP.  The  specialist  will  (i)  work  closely  with  the  international  data 
management specialist in analyzing the implications of the NEP for providing timely, accurate, 
and  complete  information  on  all  schools,  teachers,  and  students;  (ii)  take  the  lead  in  the 
consultations  supporting  this  analysis;  and  (iii)  provide  inputs  to  the  assessment  and 
examination system analysis. To provide this support, the specialist is expected to have in-
depth experience in education statistics in Bangladesh and education data collection, storage, 
and usage in Bangladesh, preferably having worked closely with BANBEIS. 
  9.  Pool of consultants (national, 6 person-months) 
12.  Funds will be provided for a pool of consultants so that specialists can be quickly 
recruited when new requirements arise.
